wikipedia_page.main:
Iain Lindsay Philip (born 9 June 1958 in Falkirk) was a Scottish cricketer. He played cricket between 1986 and 1999. He made his One-day International debut in 1999 at the age of 41 against Australia.
During his cricket-playing career he made 104 appearances for the Scottish cricket team, more than any other player, became the highest-scoring Scottish batsman, and scored more runs than any other batsman in a single innings (234 in 1991).

response: This is a list of the final 15-man squads named for the 1999 Cricket World Cup in England which took place from 14 May 1999 to 20 June 1999, in accordance to the jersey number worn. Each team had to number the players from 1 to 15 and usually captains wore the no.1 jersey. The oldest player at the 1999 Cricket World Cup was Ian Philip (40/41) of Scotland while the youngest player was Mohammad Sheikh (18) of Kenya.

Lockie was born in Alloa, Clackmannanshire, and attended Dollar Academy in nearby Dollar.Bryn Lockie – CricketArchive. Retrieved 15 March 2016. He made his senior debut for Scotland at the 1995 British Isles Championship, against Wales.Scotland cap matches played by Bryn Lockie – CricketArchive. Retrieved 15 March 2016. Playing against Ireland in the 1996 edition of the tournament, he was involved in a match-winning opening stand of 198 runs with Ian Philip, to which he contributed 70 runs.Ireland v Scotland, Triple Crown Tournament 1996 – CricketArchive. Retrieved 15 March 2016. Lockie made his first-class debut later in 1996, also against Ireland.First-class matches played by Bryn Lockie – CricketArchive. Retrieved 15 March 2016. The following year, he was selected in the Scottish squad for the 1997 ICC Trophy in Malaysia, and went on to play in six of his team's nine matches.ICC Trophy matches played by Bryn Lockie – CricketArchive. Retrieved 15 March 2016. He scored 114 runs at the tournament, with a best of 58 against Italy.Records / Carlsberg ICC Trophy, 1996/97 - Scotland / Batting and bowling averages  – ESPNcricinfo. Retrieved 15 March 2016. At the 1998 Benson & Hedges Cup, Lockie played in all four of his team's games, and scored two half-centuries – 51 against Derbyshire and 54 against Durham. He scored another List A half-century in the 1999 NatWest Trophy, making 58 against the Nottinghamshire Cricket Board.List A matches played by Bryn Lockie – CricketArchive. Retrieved 15 March 2016. Lockie's last appearances for Scotland came at the 2000 European Cricket Championship.
